    • Turn a programming project into a text-network

Turn a programming project into a text-network

vignette_get_text_network_from_project.Rmd

This vignette explain the network returned by codexplor::get_text_network_from_project. This function will compute a Citations Network of programming project(s), from local folder path(s) and/or public github repo(s). This Vignette give a basic understanding of such a network.

Example

For example, giving a bunch of .R project and/or repos :

net <- get_text_network_from_project(repos =  c("tidyverse/stringr", "clement-lvd/codexplor"))
# codexplor functions will deal with a R project by default

# get an igraph object from this edgelist, and optionnaly filter it :
codexplor::get_igraph_from_df(net) 

#get a networkD3 dataviz' from this edgelist :
get_networkd3_from_igraph(net)
.

Network properties. The returned network is a document-to-document Citations network.

Such a network have already a lot of mathematical properties that we don‚Äôt cover here (e.g., a Citations Network is always a directed network).

Regarding the network computed by codexplor::get_text_network_from_project() :

  • A node is one of the programming files (exclusively .R files by default).
  • An edge is symbolizing a link from a file that calls a function to the file where the function is defined.

Thus :

  • Indegrees of a node is ‚Äòhow many functions of the project uses this func‚Äô.
  • Outdegree of a node is ‚Äúhow many functions of the project are used by this precise function‚Äù.
  • ‚ü≤ auto-mentioning typically reveal ‚Äòrecursivity‚Äô, once a func‚Äô call itself more than one times (1st mention is usually for define the func‚Äô name)

Cascading matching operated

codexplor default pattern are aimed to extract functions names from the files of a programming project.

Assuming the user have indicated folder(s) and/or github repo(s), codexplor::get_text_network_from_project() will try to perform a ‚Äòcascading matching‚Äô :

‚è© Read the files, trying to extract a 1st pattern (e.g., defaults parameters will extract R functions names, when a func‚Äô is defined within a file).

‚è© Search for these patterns (functions names by default) in the initial content, in order to constitute a Citations Network.

üéÅ Return the edgelist of the network of documents (i.e.¬†files path with the 2nd match => files path with the 1st match [where the function is defined])

Filter undesired match

Junk nodes needs to be excluded from the network. Typical ‚Äúfalse positive‚Äù matches are the lines where you use the name of another function in a message, e.g.¬†message("my_func() is deprecated. You should use this_function() instead). get_text_network_from_files offer several parameters for deal with your style of programming.
